message: I am running python 2.6 locally though.
I have just set up djcelery/celery on my app (testfuss) but as soon as I trigger an async task I am getting the following trace: http://dpaste.de/nBgW/
Everything is working locally when using djkombu's DB transport, and running a celeryd
cool, ta
after running it the first time it actually started working
@bradwhittington Ah yes, that's a problem with the requirements on celery not being strict enough
you'll need to add redis>=2.4.5 to your requirements
though on your development machine, it works as you described it
aha, just found the issue in our uploader
had the wrong condition in an if clause, typical
indeed, it was a hangover from the old way we tested celery's existence
I think we have a #HACK somewhere, still
better than #TODO: make work!!!
"Do you exist?" 'Not sure' "Lulz" 'Lulz'.
if you used run_command, then obviously it would keep running, but that's not how we run celery round these parts
alright, new uploader code in place
I suspect there's a hole in our new uploader where it forgot to assign you one, so I'll get that fixes
*fixed

cool beans. so in the current set up of a manual runner...if I add new @task functions, or change existing ones, the worker won't be rebooted, and won't have the new functions, right? (Just checking if my understanding of celery is correct)
oh
right.
yah, see that now
hmm, has the same lack of a worker assigned
actually, the worker is rebooted whenever the code version changes, i.e. on every upload
Okay, that worked, but it seems like the celeryd workers only started up when I ran:

bradley@dev:~/src/git/lessfuss/TaskMaster/taskmaster$ epio django celeryd -- -l info


ep.io: Error: Connection to runner timed out.
Connection to upload.ep.io closed.
bradley@dev:~/src/git/lessfuss/TaskMaster/taskmaster$ epio django celeryd -- -l info
[2011-07-13 23:55:22,993: WARNING/MainProcess]
exiting the process nabs all the workers, and it stops processing the queue :/
oh, sorry, this would have been running in testfuss
hmm, yes, taskmaster hasn't been assigned a celeryd piece (i.e. told to run it all the time)
I was going off the directory name. Hold on then.
is this a new app, or one that was around before the migration?
cool :) Django and ep.io are rapidly becoming my coding mecha-suits. Thanks for the hard work, it is seriously awesome so far.
but it's probably the bit that stops Django, psycopg2 and eventlet having a war
prior to migration, first time using celery and redis
alright, I've manually assigned a worker to it, should be coming up now
of course, it'll need changing when we release the new, "run arbitary daemons" code, but hey
it'll now actually create and delete celery instance markers
Sweet, look forward to it Just Working™ when i deploy to 'production'
